itineraries.title: Botswana Grand Safari: From Chobe Elephants to Okavango Delta Waterways

visits.text: Enter Chobe National Park, Botswana's first national park proclaimed in 1968 and covering 11,700 square kilometers in the far northeast of the country. The Chobe River forms the northern boundary where the legendary elephant concentrations occur during the dry season from May through September. These are among the largest elephant gatherings anywhere in Africa, with herds of hundreds coming to drink and bathe.

Discover the Serondella area, famous for its elephant concentrations along the riverfront. The perennial waters of the Chobe rise in the northern Angolan highlands, providing year-round sustenance for remarkable wildlife populations. Game-viewing cruises on the Chobe River offer unique perspectives on elephants, hippos, and crocodiles from water level.

Explore the diverse ecosystems within Chobe, which encompasses four distinctive areas: the Savuti Channel, Linyanti, Serondella, and Nogatsaa. Each region hosts concentrations of specific wildlife-Savuti famous for lion and hyena, Linyanti for hippo and crocodile. Many species thrive here including the rare puku and Chobe bushbuck found in few other locations.

activities.text: Embark on game-viewing and bird-watching cruises along the Chobe River, where 460 bird species have been recorded including raptors, vultures, and waterbirds. The dry winter months from March through July offer exceptional viewing as animals concentrate around water sources. November to December sees the migration of herbivores between the river and Savuti Marsh.

visits.text: Journey to Savuti, a region within Chobe National Park rather than a separate reserve-though its reputation has earned it distinction among safari destinations. The area is huge, and experienced guides keep groups well apart, providing feelings of genuine remoteness. At spectacular wildlife sightings, the experience remains intimate compared to more crowded parks elsewhere in Africa.

Witness the legendary predator activity for which Savuti is renowned, as large carnivores follow herds of zebra, wildebeest, buffalo, and impala moving through the area. The barely discernible dry Savuti Channel creates unique habitat where lion and hyena populations thrive. Public campsites maintain Botswana's low-impact tourism philosophy.

activities.text: Experience camping safaris in Savuti where the remoteness and wildlife density create memorable encounters. Dawn and dusk game drives maximize chances of predator sightings as lions hunt and hyenas patrol their territories. The dramatic landscape of ancient channels and open plains provides exceptional photographic opportunities.

visits.text: Discover Tsodilo Hills, a rare and unique place with an atmosphere of intrigue and mystery. Four large pieces of rock rise unexpectedly from the dry desert expanse-referred to by the Bushmen as the 'male,' 'female,' 'child,' and the rejected first wife. These hills are believed to be the site of first Creation, where the Bushmen painted more than 3,500 rock paintings dating from 800-1300 AD.

Explore one of the most historically significant rock art sites in the world, boasting 500 individual locations representing thousands of years of human habitation. Some paintings are thought to be more than 20,000 years old, while others are merely a century old. The Bushmen believe these hills are a resting place for spirits of the deceased.

Follow different trails leading to over 350 sites, discovering paintings including the famous zebra used as the logo of Botswana's National Museums and Monuments. Certain paintings of whales and penguins suggest ancient contact between Bushmen and coastal peoples. The sacred atmosphere intensifies near the top of Male Hill where the first spirit is believed to have prayed after creating the world.

activities.text: Climb and explore the hills and trails, appreciating evidence of legends and ancient life. Visit the small Bushmen habitat nearby and the Hambukushu village near Male Hill, whose people believe their god Nyambe originally lowered their tribe to earth here. Bird watching rewards patient observers, with yellow-billed hornbills, grey louries, and Melba finches among commonly sighted species.

visits.text: Immerse yourself in the Okavango Delta, formed by a river that flows into the desert and dies in the sands, creating a great inland wetland visible from space. This is one of Africa's greatest wilderness areas, an oasis in the desert supporting astonishing biodiversity. Hundreds of islands ranging from huge Chief's Island to tiny termite mounds host diverse wildlife populations.

Explore the mosaic of channels, lagoons, and lakes formed when summer rains in Angola flood the delta. Thirty-two tree species include mopane, mangosteen, rain and sausage trees, varieties of acacia and fig. Over 1,000 types of plants thrive here-more than any similarly sized park in Africa-with characteristic reed beds and large stands of phoenix palms.

Discover the waterways inhabited by hippo, crocodiles, elephants, and antelope, where dry spots and floodplains alternate with dense woodland. The delta reaches peak water levels during the dry winter months of July through September, when the contrast between flooded channels and dry land creates exceptional game viewing. Summer months bring new growth and antelope calving.

activities.text: Experience the Okavango year-round, choosing between high-water season in winter for classic delta scenery or summer months from November through March when migrant birds arrive in numbers and antelope drop their young. Scenic flights over the delta reveal the intricate patterns of water and land that make this ecosystem unique.

visits.text: Enter Moremi Game Reserve, the officially proclaimed section of the legendary Okavango Delta. This exceptional destination combines open plains, lush riverine forest, and papyrus waterways that visitors consistently describe as incredibly beautiful and pleasing to the eye. The reserve borders Chobe National Park with no fences, allowing wildlife to roam freely between areas.

Discover 36 species of larger mammals including elephant, buffalo, giraffe, zebra, hippo, and various antelope-notably the water-loving lechwe and secretive sitatunga. Over 80 species of fish and 400 different birds inhabit these wetlands, including raptors, waterbirds, bush and tree dwellers, and breeding colonies of magnificent Goliath heron.

Experience Moremi as the accessible section of the Okavango Delta, ideal for self-drive safaris in four-wheel-drive vehicles for those seeking raw adventure. Three public campsites in the park are unfenced, bringing genuine wilderness close as all species of animals walk through. Self-drive campers must be self-sufficient with no shops available in the park.

activities.text: Glide through waterways by mokoro (traditional dugout canoe) or motorboat, an unbeatable way to experience the delta's unique ecosystem. Game drives complement water-based activities, while wilderness trails and viewing hides at certain camps offer intimate wildlife encounters. Fly-in safaris provide spectacular aerial perspectives over this watery wilderness.

visits.text: Explore Nxai Pan National Park, a fossil lakebed about 40 square kilometers in size lying north of the Maun-Nata road. The pan itself is an extensive grass plain dotted with clusters of umbrella acacia trees and mopane woodland. During the rains from November to April, the pans become covered in grass, transforming into a Garden of Eden.

Visit the legendary Baines' Baobabs, a clump of large baobab trees immortalized in 1862 by painter Thomas Baines during Livingstone's expedition. These ancient trees appear virtually unchanged from Baines' original painting, standing as silent witnesses to over 160 years of African history. The site offers exceptional photography opportunities and a tangible connection to exploration history.

Discover the focal point waterhole amid the grassy plain studded with umbrella thorn trees. Permanent residents include lion, giraffe, kudu, springbok, impala, ostrich, jackal, and bat-eared fox. Once rains begin, gemsbok, elephant, and thousands of zebra migrate to the area to drop their young, creating spectacular wildlife viewing.

activities.text: Watch for the noisy black korhaan that rises with a squeak when flushed by vehicles-a hallmark species of Nxai Pan. Small raptors including kestrel and goshawks abound, rewarding birders who keep binoculars ready. The combination of open pans, scattered trees, and diverse habitats creates excellent wildlife and bird-watching opportunities.

visits.text: Journey to the Makgadikgadi Pans, flat, featureless salt and clay depressions interspersed with sand dunes, islands of rock, grassy plains, and patches of Kalahari desert. These ancient pans were once part of a super-lake that covered much of northern Botswana. Good rains transform the pans with shallow waters that attract thousands of migrant flamingos.

Experience the sensation of vast open space, timelessness, and complete nothingness that defines these extraordinary salt flats. From December through February, the rain-filled pans host spectacular congregations of flamingos alongside pelicans, spoonbills, waders, and storks. The endless white expanse stretching to the horizon creates an otherworldly atmosphere.

activities.text: Race across the Makgadikgadi Pans on a quad bike adventure-an exhilarating and unforgettable experience across this endless 'moonscape' where nothing grows on the salty sands. The activity clears the mind and offers unique perspectives on the vast emptiness. Base yourself at lodges near Nata or Gweta for comfortable access to this remarkable landscape.

visits.text: Arrive in Francistown, one of Botswana's oldest towns and site of southern Africa's first gold rush. Home to 92,500 people, this frontier town is strategically placed as the gateway to the north, with main roads to Gaborone, Zimbabwe, Maun, and Kazungula passing through. Despite being Botswana's second-largest urban center and 'Capital of the North,' it maintains small-town character.

Explore the remnants of abandoned mines surrounding the town, testament to its gold rush heritage when prospectors from as far as Australia and America rushed here seeking fortune. Evidence of human habitation in this area extends back 80,000 years. Karl Mauch discovered gold along the Tati River in 1867, sparking the rush that made this area the 'Ophir of Africa.'

activities.text: Use Francistown as a base to explore nearby attractions including the Tuli Block to the south and the Makgadikgadi Salt Pans to the west. Accommodation meets international standards, providing comfortable access to some of Botswana's most fascinating sights. The town's industrial growth has doubled its population in recent decades while maintaining its historical character.

visits.text: Journey to the Tuli Block, historically known as the Tuli Enclave, offering quick and easy access to wilderness with guaranteed wildlife sightings. The name derives from the Tuli River in Zimbabwe, while 'Block' refers to the large piece of land stretching 10-20km wide and over 350km from north to south. The great Limpopo River gives this region its special character.

Explore the North-East Tuli Game Reserve between the Limpopo, Motlouse, and Shashe rivers, integrating the Mashatu Game Reserve and Tuli Nature Reserve. On twice-daily game drives, spot elephant, kudu, impala, wildebeest, giraffe, lion, zebra, leopard, and some black-maned lions. Over 350 bird species include shrikes, boulder chat, short-toed rock thrush, raptors, and ostriches.

Discover numerous archaeological and historical sites providing evidence of early communities through pottery shards, beads, smelting relics, and granaries. Night drives reveal caracal, aardwolf, hyena, and jackal. The spectacular confluence where the Shashe and Limpopo rivers join creates dramatic scenery that has attracted visitors since the time of Cecil John Rhodes.

activities.text: Join guided walks with Tswana rangers to visit Bushmen sites and paintings scattered throughout the reserve. The aquatic bird species are especially fascinating, including cormorants and beautiful pygmy kingfishers along the river systems. Access from Johannesburg takes approximately 5 hours via the Pont Drift border post.

seo.h1_title: Botswana Safari Itinerary: Okavango Delta, Kalahari Desert & Elephant Wilderness
seo.intro_paragraph: Watch elephants crossing the Chobe River, explore the Okavango Delta by mokoro, admire Moremi's lions and sleep under Kalahari stars. Botswana offers a wild and preserved Africa.
seo.seo_hook: Elephants cross flooded channels, lions roar across the plains, salt stretches to the horizon. Botswana embodies African wilderness.

itineraries.title: Complete Botswana Circuit in 15 Days

activities.text: Landing at Maun after a long flight via Johannesburg. The warm Kalahari air greets you on the dusty tarmac of this airport, which becomes one of Africa's busiest during peak season. Transfer to your accommodation for a first night of rest.

practical_info.airlines: Airlink and Air Botswana from Johannesburg (daily flights), Airlink from Cape Town (5x/week)
practical_info.tip: Pack warm clothes in cabin luggage - nights are cool in dry season (10-15°C)
practical_info.transfer: Lodge shuttle or taxi, negotiate price beforehand (~200 BWP)

visits.text: Full briefing at the 4x4 rental company. They explain every corner of the vehicle: the winch, compressor, jerrycans, rooftop tent setup, and sand tracks. Take notes, photograph the vehicle from all angles before signing.

practical_info.vehicle_check: Photos of every scratch/dent BEFORE departure - avoids disputes upon return
practical_info.equipment_verification: Check fridge operation, compressor, rooftop tent setup
practical_info.drop_off: One-way Maun→Kasane possible (fee ~USD 200-400 depending on company)

activities.text: Strategic supplies run in Maun. Fill the fridge with fresh meat, the trunk with canned goods and pasta, the jerrycans with water. Last reliable grocery store before Kasane in 8 days. Don't underestimate the quantities.

practical_info.water: 5L per person per day minimum - plan for 50-60L total
practical_info.food: Fresh meat for 3 days max (12V fridge), then canned goods and pasta
practical_info.fuel: Full tank + 2 jerrycans of 20L - no stations in the parks

activities.text: Scenic flight over the Okavango Delta in late afternoon. From the Cessna, the labyrinth of turquoise channels unfolds, dotted with elephant herds and palm islands. A unique perspective on this UNESCO-listed ecosystem.

practical_info.best_light: Late afternoon for golden light and long shadows
practical_info.tip: Window seat essential, avoid white clothing (reflections)

visits.text: Check-in at Moremi Game Reserve's South Gate. Formalities completed, you pass through the barrier and enter one of Africa's most pristine sanctuaries. Tarmac gives way to sand. Welcome to the bush.

practical_info.booking: Campsite reservation MANDATORY - no Kwalate/Xomae voucher = entry denied

activities.text: First self-drive safari on Moremi's tracks. Eyes fixed on the sand, you learn to read the signs: lion prints, fresh elephant dung - the bush reveals its secrets. Giraffes, zebras, impalas appear between the mopanes.

practical_info.wildlife: Elephants, giraffes, buffaloes, zebras, impalas, baboons
practical_info.rules: Stay in your vehicle - getting out is prohibited in the park

activities.text: Setting up at South Gate campsite before nightfall. Rooftop tent assembly, first campfire under the southern stars. Hyenas prowl around the camp, their cackles piercing the darkness.

practical_info.facilities: Basic ablutions, no electricity, standpipe for water
practical_info.wildlife: Hyenas, elephants and buffaloes cross the camp at night
practical_info.tip: Never walk at night - drive to the toilets

visits.text: Route to Third Bridge, the legendary campsite in the heart of the marshes. The track crosses First Bridge then Second Bridge - the latter in poor condition, detour sometimes necessary. Expect about a hundred water pools to cross after rain.

practical_info.road: Sandy track with numerous water crossings (up to 50 cm)
practical_info.condition: Second Bridge in poor condition - check before crossing
practical_info.tip: Clay soil, slow drainage - caution after rains

activities.text: Safari in the Third Bridge wetland area. Lagoons covered in water lilies harbor hippos and crocodiles. Lechwe bound through the shallow water. On the islands, buffalo herds are regularly hunted by lions.

practical_info.wildlife: Hippos, crocodiles, lechwe, buffaloes, lions, leopards (chance)
practical_info.best_loop: Mboma Loop along the reed beds - buffalo herds
practical_info.tip: Regularly check that grass isn't building up under the chassis

activities.text: Setting up at Third Bridge Camp, one of Moremi's most beautiful sites. Sites 8, 9 and 10 offer more privacy and spectacular marsh views. Baboons in the sausage trees above camp - don't leave anything lying around.

practical_info.facilities: 2 ablution blocks, concrete braai pit, no electricity
practical_info.best_sites: Sites 1-7 near ablutions and shade, sites 8-10 more secluded with views
practical_info.wildlife: Elephants, hyenas, lions cross the camp - lion tracks frequent
practical_info.tip: Hood open at night discourages lions from climbing on the vehicle

visits.text: Crossing Fourth Bridge - Moremi's longest bridge, in good condition - then exit via North Gate. You leave the national park to enter the Khwai Community Concession, a territory managed by the villagers.

practical_info.note: Khwai = community concession, no park entry fees
practical_info.office: Khwai Development Trust 1 km after the bridge - camping payment
practical_info.village: Khwai Village: bar, cold drinks, NO fuel

activities.text: Safari in the Khwai Community Concession. This buffer zone between Moremi and Chobe offers exceptional wildlife density. Elephants by the hundreds, lions, leopards and especially the highly sought-after wild dogs that sometimes establish their dens in the area.

practical_info.wildlife: Elephants, lions, leopards, wild dogs (dens in winter), hippos
practical_info.advantage: Night drives permitted (with KDT guide), mokoro on Mbudi River
practical_info.restriction: Khwai Private Reserve off-limits to self-drivers

activities.text: Setting up at Magotho Camp (also called Khwai Community Camp), 20 km east of the village. Elephants cross the campsite constantly - a magical but intimidating experience the first few times. Stay calm, keep your distance.

practical_info.facilities: 2 recent ablution blocks, braai pit, no electricity
practical_info.wildlife: Elephants cross the camp day and night - extraordinary
practical_info.tip: Riverside sites (9-15) more frequented, sites 1-8 under large trees quieter

activities.text: Early morning safari in the Khwai Concession at sunrise. Predators are still active, elephants head toward the river. Golden light illuminates the floodplains. Return to camp for breakfast.

practical_info.wildlife: Lions, leopards (excellent chances), wild dogs, hyenas
practical_info.tip: Ask local guides where the wild dog dens are

activities.text: Mokoro excursion on the Mbudi River at midday. Traditional dugout canoes glide silently through the papyrus. Hippos, crocodiles, kingfishers. A peaceful interlude before the Savuti tracks.

practical_info.booking: Book via Khwai Development Trust or directly at camp
practical_info.wildlife: Hippos, crocodiles, lechwe, birds (fish eagles, kingfishers)
practical_info.tip: Bring water, hat, sunscreen - no shade on the mokoro

activities.text: Guided night drive in the concession in late afternoon. Unlike national parks, Khwai permits night safaris. Headlights sweep the savanna searching for the glowing eyes of predators.

practical_info.booking: Mandatory with KDT guide - your vehicle, their guide
practical_info.wildlife: Hunting lions, leopards, hyenas, genets, civets
practical_info.advantage: Only place on the circuit where night drives are possible
practical_info.tip: Bring warm jacket - temperatures drop quickly after sunset

visits.text: Early departure toward Savuti. Two possible routes: Sand Ridge Route (recommended in rainy season) or Marsh Route (better in dry season). Ask for advice at Savuti camp before leaving. Prepare for 4-5 hours of demanding track.

practical_info.road: Deep sand for most of the journey - Sand Ridge particularly difficult
practical_info.tip: Deflate tires to 1.6-1.8 bar in deep sand
practical_info.fuel: NO stations in the park - check your reserves before leaving

activities.text: Entering the Savuti region, southern part of Chobe National Park. Radically different landscape: dry plains, solitary bull elephants, massive baobabs. The Savuti Channel, dry for decades, has recently come back to life.

practical_info.landscape: Dry area, open plains, periodically flooded marsh
practical_info.wildlife: Solitary bull elephants, lions, hyenas, zebras
practical_info.history: Savuti Channel stopped flowing for 30 years before resuming in 2008

activities.text: Setting up at Savuti Camp, a small campsite of about 8 sites managed by SKL. The camp is often full - reservation essential. Sites 1-4 and Paradise Camp offer views of the channel. On-site shop for firewood and cold drinks.

practical_info.facilities: Renovated ablutions, shop (firewood, drinks, snacks), no electricity
practical_info.booking: Book via SKL - camp often full, no entry without reservation

activities.text: Morning safari on the Savuti plains. This region is famous for its lions that have learned to hunt elephants - a unique behavior observed nowhere else. Predator-prey interactions are spectacular.

practical_info.wildlife: Lions (large prides), leopards, hyenas, cheetahs (rare), elephants
practical_info.fame: Savuti lions famous for hunting elephants - BBC documentaries
practical_info.best_areas: Pans north of camp, Marsh Road (if passable)

activities.text: Rest at camp during the hot hours. Animals seek shade, the heat is crushing. Nap, reading, vehicle maintenance. SKL teams come by to clean vacant sites.

practical_info.tip: Temperatures up to 40°C in October - avoid driving between 11am and 3pm
practical_info.maintenance: Check tire pressure, water level, dust in filters

activities.text: Late afternoon safari around the waterholes. Elephants converge on the pans, predators start becoming active. The sun sets over golden plains. Return to camp before gate closure.

practical_info.wildlife: Elephants at waterholes, lions in ambush, hyenas
practical_info.rules: Return to camp before 6:30pm - night driving prohibited in national parks

visits.text: Big track day: Savuti to Kasane. Count on 5 to 7 hours driving in deep sand. The route crosses mopane forests and very demanding sections. Take your time, respect the vehicle.

practical_info.road: Almost continuous deep sand, very difficult sections
practical_info.tip: Leave at dawn to arrive before dark - no night driving
practical_info.fuel: First station in Kasane - watch your gauge

activities.text: Arriving in Kasane late afternoon. First town since Maun: supermarkets, gas stations, ATMs. Your body craves a hot shower and a proper meal. Full resupply for the final days.

practical_info.facilities: Supermarkets (Kazungula, Kasane), ATMs, gas stations, mechanics
practical_info.position: Crossroads of 4 countries: Botswana, Namibia, Zambia, Zimbabwe
practical_info.tip: Fill up on fuel, withdraw cash, fresh groceries for the final days

activities.text: Night at a lodge or campsite in Kasane. After the grueling Savuti-Kasane track, a real night's rest is needed. Some lodges offer views of the Chobe River and passing elephants at dusk.

practical_info.options: Riverside lodges, Chobe Safari Lodge, equipped campsites
practical_info.advantage: Hot shower, electricity, restaurant - luxury after the bush
practical_info.wildlife: Elephants come to drink at the river at dusk from the lodges

visits.text: Morning safari on the Chobe Riverfront. Entry via Sedudu Gate, 6 km from Kasane. The track runs along the river for kilometers. Here lies the world's largest elephant concentration: 50,000 to 120,000 individuals by some estimates.

practical_info.fees: P120/person + P50/vehicle (if not already paid for Savuti)
practical_info.wildlife: Elephants by the thousands, hippos, buffaloes, crocodiles, lions (chance)

activities.text: Elephants cross the river before you, trunks intertwined to protect the young from the current. Hippos emerge snorting. Buffaloes graze by the hundreds on the islands. Chobe Riverfront offers one of the world's best water-based safaris.

practical_info.highlight: Elephants crossing the river - unforgettable sight
practical_info.wildlife: Puku, Chobe bushbuck (endemic), fish eagles, crocodiles
practical_info.tip: Several loops north descend toward the floodplains - the best viewpoints

activities.text: Sunset photo cruise on the Chobe River. The boat glides between hippos, along banks where elephants come to drink. The sun sets the sky ablaze. Cocktail in hand, you savor one of Africa's most beautiful sunsets.

practical_info.booking: Book via lodge or operator in Kasane
practical_info.wildlife: Hippos up close, drinking elephants, crocodiles, birds
practical_info.tip: Bring telephoto lens - magical light for photography

visits.text: Border crossing at Kazungula. Endless line of trucks but cars pass faster. Formalities on the Botswana side, ferry or bridge across the Zambezi, then Zimbabwean immigration. Allow 45 minutes to 3 hours depending on traffic.

practical_info.crossing: Kazungula Ferry or Kazungula Bridge (new bridge)
practical_info.documents: Passport, vehicle papers, letter from rental company authorizing crossing
practical_info.tip: Arrive early morning to avoid lines

visits.text: Zimbabwean visa on arrival. 50 USD for multiple entry, practical if you plan to go back and forth. Cash payment only. Keep your dollars handy.

practical_info.tip: Have exact change - not always change available

activities.text: Returning the 4x4 at Victoria Falls or Kasane per your contract. End of the self-drive adventure. Vehicle inspection, paperwork, transfer to your lodge. Luxury after two weeks in the bush.

practical_info.note: Some rental companies charge a drop-off fee for return outside Maun
practical_info.alternative: Return in Kasane before crossing, then shuttle transfer

activities.text: Settling in at your lodge in Victoria Falls Town. After two weeks of camping, the comfort of a real room, a pool and a restaurant feels wonderful. The town is compact, walkable, with a relaxed atmosphere.

practical_info.options: Ilala Lodge (falls view), Palm River Hotel (luxury), various lodges
practical_info.tip: Book restaurant for dinner - limited seats in high season

visits.text: Victoria Falls National Park, Zimbabwe side. Mosi-oa-Tunya - the smoke that thunders. 107 meters high, 1.7 km wide, one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World. The thunder can be heard from miles away.

practical_info.tip: Start at the end (point 16) and work back - climax at Burning Point

activities.text: Walking through the rainforest along the falls. The trail passes through a tropical forest created by the permanent spray. You will get soaked - it's unavoidable. Poncho and towel essential. Protect your camera.

practical_info.gear: Poncho, towel, waterproof bag for electronics
practical_info.best_time: Morning for fewer crowds, afternoon for light on rainbows
practical_info.wet_season: April-June: maximum flow, reduced visibility from spray
practical_info.dry_season: Sept-Dec: less water but clear views, Devil's Pool accessible

activities.text: Burning Point (point 13) offers the most spectacular view - where Zimbabwe and Zambia meet. Nearly permanent double rainbow when the sun shines. Take your time, savor the spectacle.

practical_info.highlight: Best viewpoint of the falls - complete panorama
practical_info.photo: Frequent rainbows - ideal light between 9am and 3pm
practical_info.note: Zambia border visible on the other side

activities.text: Helicopter flight over the falls - the Flight of Angels. 13 to 25 minutes of pure magic. Aerial view of the curtain of water, the Zambezi gorges, Victoria Falls Bridge. Book the front seat for unobstructed views.

practical_info.options: Flight of Angels 13-15 min ($150), Gorge Flight 22 min ($235), Zambezi Spectacular 25 min ($285)
practical_info.tip: Front seat for best view, morning for soft light
practical_info.video: Souvenir film available for purchase (25 USD)

activities.text: Zipline above the Zambezi gorges from Lookout Café. 120 meters above the void, speeds up to 100 km/h. Stunning views of both sides of the falls. For thrill seekers.

practical_info.activities: Zipline ($88), Gorge Swing ($110), Tandem Swing ($166), Flying Fox ($56)
practical_info.cafe: Restaurant with views of Batoka Gorge - perfect for recovery after
practical_info.tip: Eat AFTER activities, not before

activities.text: Sundowner at Victoria Falls Hotel or on the banks of the Zambezi. Colonial high tea, sunset cocktails, view of the falls spray in the distance. A touch of luxury to close out the adventure.

practical_info.experience: High tea or cocktails in a historic colonial setting
practical_info.tip: Book in advance during high season

visits.text: Buffer day - safety margin built into the itinerary. If a mechanical problem had occurred in the bush, this 24-hour buffer ensures you won't miss your international flight. Otherwise, enjoy!

activities.text: Relaxed morning at the lodge. Pool, spa, extended breakfast. After two intense weeks, body and mind appreciate the rest. Sort through your photos, start to realize what you've just experienced.

practical_info.tip: Back up photos to the cloud - wifi generally good in lodges

activities.text: Stroll through Victoria Falls Town and its craft markets. Wood carvings, basketwork, souvenirs. Negotiate with a smile. Elephant's Walk Shopping Village offers quality crafts.

practical_info.spots: Elephant's Walk Shopping Village, street markets
practical_info.tip: Bargaining is part of the game - start at 50% of asking price
practical_info.payment: USD cash preferred, cards accepted in formal shops

activities.text: Dinner at Three Monkeys, a local institution. Wood-fired pizzas, creative cocktails, relaxed atmosphere. Open terrace, live music some evenings. Book ahead - it's often full.

practical_info.tip: Book in high season, generous portions

visits.text: Transfer to Victoria Falls Airport. The airport is small but efficient, 20 km from town. Arrive 2.5 hours before your international flight. Last-minute souvenir shopping in the duty-free shop.

practical_info.airlines: Ethiopian Airlines, Emirates (via JNB), Kenya Airways, South African Airways, Fastjet
practical_info.tip: Arrive 2.5 hours before international flight

activities.text: International return flight via Johannesburg, Addis Ababa or Nairobi. Botswana recedes beneath the aircraft wings. Images flash by: elephants crossing the Chobe, Savuti lions, Victoria Falls spray. The adventure ends, the memories remain.

practical_info.hubs: Johannesburg (SAA, British Airways), Addis Ababa (Ethiopian), Nairobi (Kenya Airways)
practical_info.tip: Bring snacks and entertainment for the long-haul flight

seo.h1_title: Complete Botswana Circuit: 15-day 4x4 safari and camping adventure
seo.intro_paragraph: From Maun to Victoria Falls, traverse the wildest sanctuaries of Southern Africa. In complete autonomy aboard a fully-equipped 4x4, explore the Okavango Delta, track the great predators of Savuti, and finish facing the spray of Victoria Falls. An authentic adventure journey into the heart of the African bush.
seo.seo_hook: The ultimate safari: 850 km of tracks through Botswana's most beautiful reserves.
featured_list: Scenic flight over the Okavango Delta
Moremi Game Reserve and Third Bridge
Khwai: mokoro, night drives and leopards
Victoria Falls on the Zimbabwe side

places_taglines.BW::third-bridge: Legendary campsite in the heart of the marshes

segments.name: Okavango & Moremi
segments.description: Maun, scenic flight, Moremi Game Reserve, Third Bridge

segments.name: Khwai Concession
segments.description: Khwai Community, mokoro, night drives, leopards and wild dogs

segments.name: Victoria Falls
segments.description: Victoria Falls, activities, relaxation, return flight

itineraries.notes: Complete 15-day itinerary, ~850 km of tracks. MANDATORY CAMPING RESERVATIONS: Kwalate (South Gate, Xakanaxa, Ihaha) kwalatesafari@gmail.com / SKL (Savuti, North Gate) reservations@sklcamps.co.bw / Xomae (Third Bridge) xomaesites@btcmail.co.bw / KDT (Khwai Community) khwai@btcmail.co.bw. Book 3-6 months in advance during high season. Malaria prophylaxis MANDATORY. Recommended French-speaking rental: Tawana Self Drive +267 775 28837.
itineraries.subtitle: Self-drive safari from Okavango to Victoria Falls, camping and 4x4

practical_context.vehicle_type: 4x4 double cab with rooftop tent and full camping equipment
practical_context.group_type: Adventurous couple or group of 2-4 people
highlights: Scenic flight over the Okavango Delta
Bush nights with lions and hyenas calling
Legendary Savuti crossing through deep sand
Sunset cruise on the Chobe River
Face to face with Victoria Falls spray
